Jamie_Lee_Thurston:
{{short description|American country music singer}} {{Use mdy dates|date=June 2020}} {{Infobox musical artist | name = Jamie Lee Thurston | image = | image_size = | landscape = | alt = | caption = | alias = | birth_place = [[Montpelier, Vermont]], U.S.{{cite book|last=Whitburn|first=Joel|title=Hot Country Songs 1944 to 2008|publisher=Record Research, Inc|date=2008|page=420|isbn=978-0-89820-177-2}} | origin = [[Nashville, Tennessee]] | genre = [[Country music|Country]] | occupation = Singer-songwriter | instrument = Vocals, guitar | years_active = 2003–present | label = View 2, [[Warner Bros. Records|Warner Bros.]], Country Thunder, Snakebit }} '''Jamie Lee Thurston''' is an American [[country music]] singer. He was raised in [[Waterbury, Vermont]] and performed with his father starting at age 15. After moving to Los Angeles, California, he moved again to [[Nashville, Tennessee]] in 1999.{{cite web|url=http://www.countryweekly.com/vault/jamie-lee-thurston-straight-shooter|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20160304052945/http://www.countryweekly.com/vault/jamie-lee-thurston-straight-shooter|archivedate=March 4, 2016|title=Jamie Lee Thurston: Straight Shooter|date=March 3, 2003|work=[[Country Weekly]]|accessdate=February 21, 2013}} In 2003, he released the album ''I Just Wanna Do My Thing'' via View 2. The album included the single "It Can All Be Gone", which peaked at number 59 on the [[Hot Country Songs]] charts. He later signed to [[Warner Bros. Records]] Nashville, then to Country Thunder.{{cite web|url=https://www.countryaircheck.com/email_publication/CAT_02_20_07/|title=Country Aircheck|date=February 20, 2007|accessdate=February 21, 2013}} Thurston wrote [[Rodney Atkins]]' 2009 single "[[15 Minutes (Rodney Atkins song)|15 Minutes]]", and cuts by [[Trace Adkins]] and [[Montgomery Gentry]].{{cite web|url=http://www.jamieleethurston.com/bio.php |title=Bio |work=Jamie Lee Thurston |accessdate=February 21, 2013 |url-status=dead |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20130115211604/http://www.jamieleethurston.com/bio.php |archivedate=January 15, 2013 }} In 2013, Thurston appeared on [[Game Show Network]]'s ''[[Family Trade]]'' to compose a jingle for G. Stone Motors in exchange for a new truck.{{cite episode|series=Family Trade|network=[[Game Show Network]]|date=April 16, 2013|season=1|number=8}} The jingle, "We Trade for Anything" was also used as the show's opening credits theme music. Thurston's life is the basis of a screenplay co-written by Tim Rhys, the founder of ''[[MovieMaker]]'' magazine. ==Discography== ===Albums=== {| class="wikitable plainrowheaders" style="text-align:center;" |- ! style="width:20em;"| Title ! style="width:12em;"| Album details |- ! scope="row"| ''I Just Wanna Do My Thing'' | * Release date: 2009 * Label: CD Baby * Format: CD |- ! scope="row"| ''Where's an Outlaw When You Need One'' | * Release date: 2010 * Label: Snakebit * Format: CD |- ! scope="row"| ''The Stayin Kind'' | * Release date: 2012 * Label: CD Baby * Format: CD |} ===Singles=== {| class="wikitable plainrowheaders" style="text-align:center;" |- ! rowspan="2"| Year ! rowspan="2" style="width:12em;"| Single ! colspan="1"| Peak chart
